meanings.def: at or near the back of something
examples: front and rear windows
the rear entrance of the building
A trailer was attached to the rear of the truck.
There are toilets at both front and rear of the plane.
A high gate blocks the only entrance to the rear.
Car seats for young babies should face the rear.
The radio is loudest in the rear of the car.
The socket for the printer cable is located at the rear of the computer.

meanings.def: the part of the body that you sit on
examples: a kick in the rear
He spends all day sitting on his rear end in front of a computer.

meanings.def: to be at the back of a line of people, or last in a race
examples: David was the first to reach the summit, followed by Pat, leaving Fergus to bring up the rear.
Three drummers brought up the rear.

idioms.def: to be at the back of a line of people, or last in a race
examples: David was the first to reach the summit, followed by Pat, leaving Fergus to bring up the rear.
Three drummers brought up the rear.

meanings.def: to care for young children or animals until they are fully grown
examples: She reared a family of five on her own.
Lions usually manage to rear about half the number of cubs born to them.

meanings.def: to keep and breed (= produce young from) animals or birds, for example on a farm
examples: to rear cattle
intensively reared beef cattle
naturally reared pork and beef
The young crocodiles were reared indoors at a constant temperature of 32°C.

meanings.def: to raise itself on its back legs, with the front legs in the air
examples: The horse reared, throwing its rider.

meanings.def: to seem to lean over you, especially in a way that makes you feel frightened
examples: The great bulk of the building reared up against the night sky.

meanings.def: if something unpleasant rears its head or rears its ugly head, it appears or happens

idioms.def: if something unpleasant rears its head or rears its ugly head, it appears or happens
